name: Javascript
desc: Javascript is the language of the web. I've been using Javascript for many years now, and have experience writing for enterprise-grade web applications. Practically all of my personal projects start or end with JS -- it's one of my favorite languages. I'm considering reading the entire ECMAScript spec and writing a JavaScript implementation of my own to dive deeper into the internals, some day.

name: Angular
desc: Angular is Google's open-source framework for single-page applications. I've written a handful of applications in Angular -- including this website! Coming from a background in ASP Web Forms, Angular feels like pure magic, and makes writing front-end code fun and efficient.

name: Creative Cloud
desc: Creative Cloud is Adobe's subscription service for the Adobe Creative Suite (Photoshop, Illustrator, Premiere, After Effects, et al). I've been doing graphic design and video production since long before I got into programming, and Adobe's products are the industry standard. I tend to prefer open-source alternatives to Photoshop/Illustrator (Gimp/Inkscape, respectively), but I can't live without Premiere.

name: C#
desc: C# is Microsoft's managed object-oriented language. I have a good deal of experience in C#, including enterprise applications, and have a decent grasp on the internals (Value/Ref types, IL, garbage collection, and the like). C# is lovely to write in, but tends to lead to heavier apps than I like thanks to CLR, JIT, .NET, and other three-letter acronyms.

name: CSS
desc: CSS is the style definition language of the web. I have extensive experience in CSS, and have been using it since I first started learning programming. I don't hold any strong opinions on CSS, other than that IE/Edge needs to hurry up and support Grid already.

name: Docker
desc: Docker is a platform for building truly portable, hyper-scalable networked applications that carry their dependencies with them in a transparent, lightweight way. I've been using Docker for over a year now, and try to incorporate it into every personal project of mine for the incredible perks it provides. Docker is an amazing piece of technology.

name: .NET
desc: Microsoft's .NET is the ubiquitous library/framework/platform on which VB, C#, and F# are inextricably tied. I have a good deal of enterprise experience dealing with ASP.NET Web Forms and Web API 2 applications, and have at least glanced at an ASP MVC manual before. .NET provides a nice collection of functionality for the ecosystem, at the cost of being quite heavy -- though .NET Core is supposedly going to fix that.

name: Fedora
desc: Fedora is a free, open-source operating system in the Red Hat Linux family. I've been using Fedora for a few months now, and my laptop is currently running the desktop variant.

name: Git
desc: Git is the wildly popular open-source version control system. I use Git on every single project I am actively developing. Git is everything I could ever have wanted from my version control, and a whole ecosystem of useful tools besides. Even when I use TFVC, I use Git to fill in the gaps.

name: Go
desc: Go is Google's imperative structured programming language, designed to make building high-performance (possibly concurrent) applications simple, straightforward, and fun. I've been using Go for a year or two now, and have built a handful of applications using Go web services. I was blown away the first time I read about Go interfaces. Go is without a doubt my favorite language -- it's C without the memory management, or C# without the object-oriented bloat. Writing Go programs is fast, fun, and refreshing.

name: Haskell
desc: Haskell is a very high level functional programming language. I've been learning Haskell for the past two years. Haskell is a beautiful and pure language, but building anything non-trivial in the language requires a deep understanding of highly esoteric mathematical concepts. Whenever I finally feel comfortable writing programs in Haskell, it will be my favorite language, hands-down.

name: HTML5
desc: HTML5 is the latest iteration of HTML. It goes without saying that I have extensive HTML experience, including some of the HTML5-exclusive elements. I'm still learning the <canvas> API, however.

name: IIS
desc: Microsoft's strangely-titled Internet Information Services is the Windows platform for configuring, managing, and deploying web applications. I have industry experience configuring IIS, including complex multi-application SSL setups.

name: Java
desc: Java is the standard for managed object-oriented languages. I have several years of Java experience.

name: jQuery
desc: jQuery is a DOM manipulation + kitchen sink library for Javascript. I have extensive experience using jQuery, including enterprise applications. jQuery is good at what it does, but what it does is rapidly becoming obsolete with the rise of MVC frameworks.

name: MySQL
desc: MySQL is a free and open source SQL RDBMS. I have some experience working with MySQL, but considerably more experience with Microsoft SQL Server / T-SQL.

name: nginx
desc: nginx is an infinitely-configurable, high-performance, hyper-scaling web server. I have a good amount of experience using nginx, and use it in nearly every project I make. nginx is simple, intuitive, and blazingly fast.

name: Node.js
desc: Node.js is the software platform and ecosystem for server-side Javascript applications. I have a good amount of experience with Node.js.

name: PHP
desc: PHP Hypertext Preprocessor, or PHP, is a dynamically-typed scripting language for generating HTML server-side on the fly. I have a great deal of experience with PHP, though it has been a long time since I've used it in any project. PHP was my introduction to web programming, and while I loved it at the time, Javascript is still my go-to for writing web applications.

name: Python
desc: Python is a deliberately simple scripting language, with an emphasis on code readability and ease of development. I have a fair amount of experience with Python, including working with deep-learning neural network libraries. Python is a nice language for building things quickly, though I still prefer Javascript for my prototyping.

name: React
desc: React is a Javascript-based front-end MVC framework for single page web applications, among other things. I'm currently in the process of learning React.

name: Redis
desc: Redis is an in-memory NoSQL database management system. I've used Redis on a few projects before. It's easy to set up, and works wonderfully with Docker web app setups.

name: Sass
desc: Sass is a preprocessor for CSS which extends the language with all sorts of wonderful features. I've been using Sass for a year or two now. After using Sass for the first time, I never want to go back to writing CSS by hand again.

name: SQL Server Management Studio
desc: SQL Server Management Studio is the software console for managing Microsoft's SQL Server RDBMS. I have about a year of experience working with SSMS, including deep experience making optimizations using the query profiler. SSMS is a pretty convenient tool for managing SQL server, and there's really no limit to the ways you can configure your database with it.

name: Sublime Text
desc: Sublime Text is a cross-platform text editor that is endlessly extensible and customizable. I've been using Sublime Text for many years now. It's my favorite text editor by a long-shot. It's light, fast, and efficent, and there's always a macro, shortcut, or package that does exactly what you need it to -- plus, even if there isn't, you can easily write one in Python.

name: TensorFlow
desc: TensorFlow is Google's math-graphing library, best known for its many tools for building deep-learning neural networks. I've built an app on top of TensorFlow before, and I have another one planned for the near future.

name: Team Foundation Server
desc: Microsoft's Team Foundation Server is the integrated ticket, build, deployment, and version control system designed for use with Visual Studio. I have industry experience working with TFS and TFVC projects.

name: T-SQL
desc: T-SQL, or Transact-SQL, is Microsoft's implementation of SQL with support for transactions, used for Microsoft SQL Server. I have industry experience working with T-SQL.

name: TypeScript
desc: Microsoft's TypeScript is an extension for Javascript to add object-oriented paradigms and compiler-enforced strict types. I've been using TypeScript for a few months now (primarly with Angular 2). TypeScript is exactly what it sounds like: Javascript, with strict typing. In that respect, it's close to a perfect language.

name: Ubuntu
desc: Ubuntu is a hugely popular Debian-based Linux operating system distribution. I've used Ubuntu Desktop and Server platforms for years. Ubuntu was my gateway into the Linux world, and while it's comfortable, I found it to be a bit heavy and unstable for my taste.

name: Visual Studio
desc: Microsoft's Visual Studio is the industry-standard IDE for Windows. I have industry experience working with Visual Studio, including TFS and TFVC integrations.

name: Firebase
desc: Firebase is Google's cloud platform for web & mobile applications. I've used Firebase for a few projects -- including this website! Firebase is pretty incredible, and when I discovered that it offers a free tier, I immediately changed over my web hosting.

name: Cloud Firestore
desc: Cloud Firestore is a real-time NoSQL database solution built into Firebase. I've used Cloud Firestore for a few projects -- including this website! Cloud Firestore is a relatively normal NoSQL DBMS, but it's the real-time binding that makes it feel like magic.
